mods.note: M/9/r/6y 2.9 PFG1951 V/ Y © No.TO/SO-Misc. SULTANATE OF MUSCAT & OMAN MINISTRY OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS MUSCAT 24th December, 1951. Sir, I have the honour to refer to your letter No. 21/9/1/51, dated the 20th December 1951, and to say that the Sultan has given his consent to the Senior Naval Officer, Persian Gulf, flying his ilag on H. M. S. 'Flamingo, to make the visits mentioned in your letter. I have the honour to be. Sir, Your obedient servant. Minister for Fore airs. His Britannic Majesty’s Consul, Muscat. > (Msh) INDEXRESTRICTED 1213A0. The Political Agency, Muscat. WITH THE COMPLIMENTS OF HIS MAJESTY’S POLITICAL RESIDENCY Su £^ ^ o? BRITISH RESIDENCY, Bahrain. 18 th December, 1951 * PERSIAN GULF.TELEGRAM. 21/1///S(. Clear From :— MUSCAT To BAHRAIN • AND BASRAH. Despatched December 24 Received Xo. 241 of December 24 Addressed to Bahrain telegram No. 241 of December 24th and Basrah /'No. 27 for SNOPG. 3ultan has approved Flamingo \ visit to Bandar Khairan, Sur and Masirah. GETHIN index Wt. 23623/396 10m. 9.50 Wa. & Co. G51/3.21/9/1/51 British Consulate, Muscat* December 20, 1951. Sir, I have the honour to put forward a request from the Senior Naval Officer, Persian Gulf, flying his flag in H.M.3. Flamingo, that he may be permitted to make visits to Bandar y hairam from 15th to 16th January 1952, Sur from 16th to 18th January and Masirah from 19th to 22nd January* I should be grateful if I may be informed whether His Highness the Sultan will give his consent to these visits. I have the honour to be. Sir, Your obedient Servant, J, f^ethin The Minister for Foreign Affairs, Muscat.20/9/1/51 British Consulate Muscat. December 24,1951 Peer »4uesue ^ In the course of the Resident’s visit here, we discussed with S r 0PG the question of obtaining the Sultan’s ap roval of the Flamingo’s proposed visit to Bandar Khairam, Sur and Masirah, which I undertood to secure urgently, although no official request had yet arrived here through the Residency. 2. Today there has arrived from the Residency, n t a re uest that I obtain the Sultan’s sanction, but a copy of a letter from Graham to 3N0PG conveying approval of the trip. Surely something has gone wrong s .mewhere. Nothing further need be done in connexion with this particular visit, since I have already ap roached the Muscat! authorities - indeed, by the time you see this, I hope you will also have the answer. But there seems to be some need for a recognised procedure. C.M. Le Quesne, Esq., British Residency, Bahrain. Yours sinoerely f J # Gethln INDEXThe Political Agent, Muscat. WITH THE COMPLIMENTS OF HIS MAJESTY’S POLITICAL RESIDENCY BRITISH RESIDENCY, BAHRAIN. PERSIAN GULF.(1041/168) BRITISH mSSIDENCI BAH^AIK. T 1 : ■ 16 th Noveniber, 1951. I an afraii I cannot let you have a very definite reply to yjur message No. 121122S. As you will see from a copy of a letter which I an sending you, T have already asked the foreign Office to let i^c .ave as soon as possible a forecast of the date on which the Treaty papers are likely to reach me here. The oreign Office bag now arrives here on Sunday evenings and T thin’ therefore that the Treaty papers are likely to reach us either on the 9th or 1 >th December. If they arrive on the earlier date I would sug cst that I should leave here on the 13 th December so as to ar rive at Muscat at 8.a.on the 15th. I should then like if possible to spend three days at huscat and one lay on the Batvnah coast. 2. If however the oapers arrive on the l^tr, as is core probable, I suggest th t I should embark p.m. on t e 1?th so as to reach i'u cat at a.in. on the 19 th. ^his .'iroull o. ly give me two days 19th-2>t£ lo get through all mj business out I think that trds can be managed. The Sultan wants depart.xe to be official and unless he is willing to allow chis on a Friday it i^eans that I '411 nave to re-emoark before sunset on the 20th. 3* I ' ill let you know as so n as I hear anything definite from the k)rei^n Jffice. It may turn out that I shall have to postpone sy trip until after the l ew Tear but I very much hope that this *.ii! not be the case. /f. 1 a : sending you a soar© copy of this letter to pass to H.K.S! 'Flamingo' if you so desire. ( .S. lay). Comnodore A. II. Wallis, R.N., Senior 1 aval Officer, ersian Gulf. <s>®NAVAL MESSAGE. FROM: SNOPG RESTRICTED TO: P.R.P. G. ROUTINE INFO: FLAMINGO. D. T.G. 121122D. (M.S.O. CORRECTION) IN VIEW OF NECESSITY FOR ARRANGING SHIP STORING AND MAINTENANCE PROGRAMMES IN ADVANCE REQUEST I MAY BE GIVEN FULLEST NOTICE OF YOUR PROPOSED DATES OF VISIT TO MUSCAT FOR SIGNING OF TREATY. 2. YOU WILL OF COURSE ALSO APPRECIATE THAT IT IS MOST UNDESIRABLE FLAMINGO TO HAVE TO FOREGO HER PROGRAMME VISIT TO BAS^A TO BASRA ^OF CHRISTMAS. THIS WILL BE NECESSARY UNLESS SHE CAN LEAVE MUSCAT BY 21st DECEMBER AT THE LATEST. 3. I SHOULD BE GRATEFUL IF 'OU CAN LET ME r NO’' WHAT NOTICE I CAN EXPECT OF DATES YOU Y.TSH TO ARRIVE AT MUSCAT AND LENGTH OF TIME YOU WOULD LIKE FLAMINGO TO REMAIN THERE. D. T. G. 121122D. BIST: A.B.C. 1.2A. HAND TO BOTH. TOD/ l/T. 2/l1TELEGRAM. To: P.R.P.G. Prom: S.R.O.P.G. RESTRICTED ROUTINE. Request clearance be obtained for visit of H.M.S. DALRYMPLE to Masira Island from 23rd to 25 th November inclusive, while on passage to Persian Gulf. D.T.G 251008 D,isocpw h~ s> 18th October 1951 —'To, His Britannic Majesty's Consul#, MUSCAT. Respected Sir, With reference t» your letter No.ll/9/l/51 dated the 14th inst I am pleased t. info™ you that it will be quite convenient for ny Club to play a match with H.M.S Loch Quioch on the 21st of this month. Obedient ley yours, t)05f factH P Secretary Nadi—el—Ittihad*,12/9/1/51. H. B.M’s Consulate, MUSCAT. 16th, October, 1951. My dear Saiyid Tarik, It is hoped to raise a soccer team to ground to he used. 2 I am not sure on which day the match will he played and the final arrangements will have to await the arrival of the ship. 3 . Would you care tolplay yourself, or to suggest the names of two or three players who would like to he in the team. Yours sincerely, Saiyid Tarik hin Taimur, MUSCAT.No. 11/9/1/51 H.B.M’s Consulate, fuscat A? 14th October, 1951. Thank you for your letter of 11th October regard!n, a hockey match against a team from II# M, S* Loch Quioch# Pinal arrangements will have to await the arrival of the ship, but I hope it will be possible to arrange a match on the 21st or 22nd October. .ould you please let me know if either of these dates should be convenient to your Club ? I am Sir, • Your obedient servant Secretary of Uadi-el-Ittihad I.'atrah# tMatrah. 11th October 1951. ELI LOT ISri His Britannic Majesty f s Consul, Muscat. Dear Sir, toe shall be most grateful if you will please arrange for our club to play a frienaly match with the members of the warship which is aue to arrive here after a short time. S. 0 Loch ^olch u Please reier to your letter No. 6 /y/l/oi, aated the 4th October i^bl. 2. Tiie Sultan nas asiced me to say that ne will oe glad to welcome H. M. S. ' Loch '^uoich ” out to observe that the proposed date of arrival,the lytn of October, is a Friday. If she arrives on this day the Mirani Battery will reply to her salute to the country but the Sultan would prefer that the official call should taKe place on tne following day, Saturday , at io. a. m. 3 # I mentioned the suggestion of lunch on board but the Sultan has asked to be excused. Muscat I regret that for operational reasons WILDGOOSE’S visit to Muscat must he cancelled. 2 . I am very sorry indeed that this is necessary'x’he Political Agency, Muscat. location.physicalLocation: British Library: India Office Records and Private Papers

physicalDescription.extent: The file is arranged in chronological order from the rear to the front.

Foliation: the foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 48, these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio.A previous foliation sequence, which is also circled, has been superseded and therefore crossed out.

mods.abstract: Correspondence and other papers relating to the visits of British Navy vessels to Muscat and other ports and islands within Muscat territories. Most of the papers are notifications of the arrival and departure of HM ships into and out of Muscat. Particular attention is given to the official visit of HMS Loch Quoich, with arrangements for cocktail parties and football and hockey matches covered by the file. Other ships mentioned include HMS Wild Gooseand Flamingo.Correspondence comes from: the Political Agent, Muscat; the Persian Gulf Residency, Bahrain; the Senior Naval Officer in the Persian Gulf; Basil Woods Ballard, Minister for Foreign Affairs, Muscat; and secretaries of sporting clubs in Muscat and Matrah.
